Do you feel safe?
University of Auckland

An activity can be defined as a task or set of tasks a learner must complete. Provide a clear statement of the task and consider any conditions that may help or hinder the learner in the performance of the task.
Describe the tasks the learners should complete.

Crime is one of the most major problems not only in Mexico but around the world. Some people do not work to obtain the things they want so they think it is easier to take them from others. No one has the right to take anyway anything from another person that does not belong to them, it is supposed to be a society norm,  however, crimes do not stop. Every day in the newspapers or in the TV news, crimes and criminals are a trending topic. 

Before we move on, answer these questions in your portfolio.

1. Have your ever been the victim of a crime? If so, explain thse situation.

2. Are some parts of this city considered more dangerous than others? Which parts?

3. Do you think there is a link between drugs and crime?

4. What are some things people can do to protect themselves from crime?

5. Why do people commit crimes?

Survey
Before you continue...
Enter a question for learners to reflect upon.
Describe how learners will assess how they have done in the exercise (rubrics are useful devices for providing reflective feedback).
University of Auckland

Reflection is a teaching method often used to connect theory to practice. Reflection tasks often provide learners with an opportunity to observe and reflect on their observations before presenting these as a piece of academic work. Journals, diaries, profiles and portfolios are useful tools for collecting observation data. Rubrics and guides can be effective feedback tools.
Enter a question for learners to reflect upon.
Reflective question:
This activity is destined for English IV, if you have a lower level it might be difficult for you to comprehend and answer some activities.
Describe how learners will assess how they have done in the exercise (rubrics are useful devices for providing reflective feedback).
Free Text
University of Auckland

The majority of a learning resource will be establishing context, delivering instructions and providing general information. This provides the framework within which the learning activities are built and delivered.
Use this field to enter text. This iDevice has no emphasis applied although limited formatting can be applied to text through the text editing buttons associated with the field.
Free Text

In this learning object you will learn about types of crimes and criminals and the vocabulary involved, you will analize information about the main causes of these social problems. You will be able to understand the use of some phrasal verbs to express criminal activity and you will create your own sentences using them.
What is a crime?
Free Text
University of Auckland

The majority of a learning resource will be establishing context, delivering instructions and providing general information. This provides the framework within which the learning activities are built and delivered.
Use this field to enter text. This iDevice has no emphasis applied although limited formatting can be applied to text through the text editing buttons associated with the field.
Free Text

Read the information about the causes of crimes, if you find any unknown word, you can look it up in the dictionary. 

Before we can discuss the causes of crime, it is first necessary to determine what we mean by the word “crime”. The legal definition of crime refers to “an action or omission which constitutes an offence” and involves some sort of punishment. Crime is one of the most prevalent problems in any society. People live in fear and are even afraid to leave their houses. It is a constant concern of whether you will be the next victim or not. 

 As society changes, some actions which used to be criminal are no longer so. Likewise some actions which were legal can become prohibited. Laws are made by the politicians we elect democratically. In a democratic society someone charged with a crime has the opportunity to defend him/herself. He or she will be deemed innocent until proven guilty by a criminal court. Punishments traditionally reflect the seriousness of the crime, the most serious are those which involve violence and/or loss of life.

In today’s world, people commit criminal offenses, get away with them and prosecute other people for the same crimes they committed. People commit crimes due to various reasons. The causes of crime are complex, even though we can have an idea to explain why these horrible situations happen. 

Overpopulation is considered one of the main causes of crime. For several years population has been increasing faster than many vital non-renewable and renewable resources. This means the amount of these resources per person is declining, in spite of modern technology. The more people on the planet, the less resources there will be.

Overpopulation leads to poverty, which is another reason is conduct to crime. The rich are continuing to get richer, and the poor get poorer. Living in poverty can get frustrating making people do unethical acts such as prostitution, and corruption among many. In our cities the highest delinquency and crime rates are in the slum areas, for perfectly understandable reasons. Here are the poorest housing conditions, the largest families, the smallest incomes, the worst health problems, the largest number of homes with parents who have themselves been in trouble with the law, and the least supervision over children. In these places gangs are formed and children learn the evil side of the world too early. 

However, it cannot be generalized, many slum children grow up in a decent way. Here is when education plays a very important role. Not just the education received in the schools but the values learned at home, the love and the attention they receive. Family violence and other issues are also related to crime in many ways.

Other factors that are important to be considered to know the causes of crime are mental health, drugs and unemployment. Depression is also a major cause of crime. Other than depression, people with grave mental disorders also end up committing crimes. A person under depression or some other serious mental disorder can also easily cause harm to themselves. Drugs are a big problem too. A drug addict ends up committing crimes to raise money for their habits. Besides that there are also a large number of people that are involved in the drug trade: cartels, politicians and even the governments. 

Besides the list of the factors already mentioned to be the causes of a crime, it cannot be just that, other factors can be involved. Every crime is different, just as every criminal.
Provide instruction on how the cloze activity should be completed. Default text will be entered if there are no changes to this field.

There are several words in the text, match the words with its definition. 

victim          innocent          criminal court          punishment             guilty          offense           gang          slum
University of Auckland
If this option is checked, submitted answers with different capitalization will be marked as incorrect.

1. A criminal court is a law court that deals with criminal cases. 

2. A gang is a group of criminals who work together. 

3. The act of punishing someone is a punishment

4. Someone who has not commited a crime is innocent.

5. Guilty : someone responsible for breaking the law. 

6. An offense is an illegal act; crime.

7. A victim is someone who has been hory or killed. 

8.  Slum : a very poor and crowded area.
If this option is set, each word will be marked as the learner types it rather than all the words being marked the end of the exercise.

To select words to hide, double click on the word to select it and click on the Hide/Show Word button below.

More than one possible answer can be defined enclosing them with pipes (|). I.e.: |dog|cat|bird|

If left unchecked a small number of spelling and capitalization errors will be accepted. If checked only an exact match in spelling and capitalization will be accepted.

For example: If the correct answer is Elephant then both elephant and Eliphant will be judged "close enough" by the algorithm as it only has one letter wrong, even if "Check Capitalization" is on.

If capitalization checking is off in the above example, the lowercase e will not be considered a mistake and eliphant will also be accepted.

If both "Strict Marking" and "Check Capitalization" are set, the only correct answer is "Elephant". If only "Strict Marking" is checked and "Check Capitalization" is not, "elephant" will also be accepted.

2. A gang is a group of criminals who work together.

5. Guilty : someone responsible for breaking the law. 

6. An offense is an illegal act; crime.

7. A victim is someone who has been hory or killed. 

8.  Slum : a very poor and crowded area.

Cloze exercises are texts or sentences where students must fill in missing words. They are often used for the following purposes:

  1. To check knowledge of core course concepts (this could be a pre-check, formative exercise, or summative check).
  2. To check reading comprehension.
  3. To check vocabulary knowledge.
  4. To check word formation and/or grammatical competence.

If your goal is to test understanding of core concepts or reading comprehension

Write a summary of the concept or reading long enough to adequately test the target's knowledge, but short enough not to induce fatigue. Less than one typed page is probably adequate, but probably considerably less for young students or beginners.

Select words in the text thatare key to understanding the concepts. Thesewill probably be verbs, nouns, and key adverbs.Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test vocabulary knowledge

Write a text using the target vocabulary. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Highlight the target words in the text. Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test word formation/grammar:

Write a text using the target forms. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Remember that the goal is not vocabulary knowledge, so the core meanings of the stem words should be well known to the students.

Highlight the target words in the text. Provide alternatives with the same word stem, but different affixes. It is a good idea to get a colleague to test the test/exercise to make sure there are no surprises!
Enter any feedback you wish to provide the learner with-in the feedback field. This field can be left blank.
Provide instruction on how the cloze activity should be completed. Default text will be entered if there are no changes to this field.
Summarize the text in the next paragraph. Read the paragraph below and fill in the missing words.
University of Auckland
If this option is checked, submitted answers with different capitalization will be marked as incorrect.

Crime refers to an action or omission which constitutes an offence that will involve a punishment . One of the most frequent problems in society is crime . Crimes change as society changes, something that now is considered a crime cannot be one in a short time; it will depend on the laws. Laws are created by the government to protect the population. Even though rules exist, crimes still happen .

It is difficult to know the exact cause why a crime is committed. There are several ideas. Overpopulation,  which leads to poverty, is considered one of the main causes of crime. Poor people can do unethical acts such as prostitution and  corruption, where education plays an important role to stop it. Other factors are mental health , drugs and unemployment.

Types of crimes and criminals
Crimes and criminals
University of Auckland

An activity can be defined as a task or set of tasks a learner must complete. Provide a clear statement of the task and consider any conditions that may help or hinder the learner in the performance of the task.
Describe the tasks the learners should complete.

In English, there are a lot of specific words for different types of crimes and the criminals who commit them. Unfortunately, the list of crimes and criminals is long because the words have specific legal meanings.

Here is a list of the most common crimes and who commits them. In case that you need a clearer definition, you can consult the dictionary. 

CRIME DEFINITION  CRIMINAL
murder killing someone on purpose murderer
kidnapping taking people away by force and demands money to free them kidnapper
burglary to enter a building, often while no one
is in it, and steal money or objects		 burglar
mugging to take something by force
from someone, often in the
street		 mugger
pickpocketing to steal from someone’s pocket
etc, without them realizing		 pickpocket
arson setting fire to a building, cars or property on purpose arsonist
rape forcing someone to have sex rapist
hijacking to use force to take control of a plane, ship, train, etc. hijacker
fraud to deceive or cheat
someone to get money		  -
theft stealing, in general, usually without violence thief
smuggling taking things secretly in or out of a place like drugs, etc. smuggler
shoplifting stealing something from a store shoplifter
manslaughter killing someone by accident   -
blackmail threatening to reveal someone’s secrets if a lot of money is not paid blackmailer
bribery giving money or granting favors to influence another person’s decisions or behavior briber
spying secretly gets information about another country spy
robbery stealing large amounts of money with force or violence from a bank, store, etc. robber
University of Auckland

Although more often used in formal testing situations MCQs can be used as a testing tool to stimulate thought and discussion on topics students may feel a little reticent in responding to. When designing a MCQ test consider the following:
  • What learning outcomes are the questions testing
  • What intellectual skills are being tested
  • What are the language skills of the audience
  • Gender and cultural issues
  • Avoid grammar language and question structures that might provide clues
Enter the question stem. The quest should be clear and unambiguous. Avoid negative premises as these can tend to be ambiguous.

When building an MCQ consider the following:
  • Use phrases that learners are familiar with and have encountered in their study
  • Keep responses concise
  • There should be some consistency between the stem and the responses
  • Provide enough options to challenge learners to think about their response
  • Try to make sure that correct responses are not more detailed than the distractors
  • Distractors should be incorrect but plausible
Enter the question stem. The quest should be clear and unambiguous. Avoid negative premises as these can tend to be ambiguous.

The majority of a learning resource will be establishing context, delivering instructions and providing general information. This provides the framework within which the learning activities are built and delivered.
Use this field to enter text. This iDevice has no emphasis applied although limited formatting can be applied to text through the text editing buttons associated with the field.
Free Text

In order to understand better crime contexts you have to learn some phrasal vrbs that are related to. 

PHRASAL VERB MEANING  EXAMPLE
beat up  to brutally attack and injure someone

The police officers beat up the protesters. 
break into to illegally enter someone's house

The girl saw him braking into her neighbor's house.
lock up to be put in jail

My best friend was locked up last year because he stole a car.
break out of  to escape from captivity

My lawyer did not help Juan break out of prison.
walk off with to steal or take something

 

The theft walked off with the money and the police did not notice. 
hold up to take money from a person or a business with a threat of violence. 

 

The man who held up the bank died after the police man shot him.
tip off to inform the police about a criminal or a crime

Greg tipped police off on his car phone about a suspect drunk driver
let off te release someone with little or no punishment

I’ll let you off this time, but don’t do it again.
take someone in  to deceive or trick someone 

 

He took me in completely with his sad story.
put someone up to  to encourage or convince someone to do something stupid or dangerous

Did your friends put you up to this?’ ‘No, it was my own idea
DropDown Activity
Provide instruction on how the dropdown activity should be completed.
Choose the correct verb to complete each definition.

1. Walk off with : to steal something or take something without asking permission. 

2. Put someone up to : to encourage someone to do something.

3. Tip off : a warning or imformation that something may happen.

4. Beat up : to hit someone hard and repeatedly. 

5. Take someone in : to fool someone.

6. Hold up :  taking another's property unlawfully and by force.

7. Let off : to release.

8. Break into : to enter illegally. 

9.  Lock up : to be in jail.

10. Break out of : to escape.

Enter the text for the dropdown activity in to the dropdown field by either pasting text from another source or by typing text directly into the field.

To select words to choose, double click on the word to select it and click on the 'Hide/Show' button below.

Optional: Write other words to complete the dropdown activity.
Use | (vertical bar ) to separate words.
This field can be left blank.

2. Put someone up to : to encourage someone to do something.

3. Tip off : a warning or imformation that something may happen.

4. Beat up : to hit someone hard and repeatedly. 

5. Take someone in : to fool someone.

6. Hold up :  taking another's property unlawfully and by force.

7. Let off : to release.

8. Break into : to enter illegally. 

9.  Lock up : to be in jail.

10. Break out of : to escape.

DropDown exercises are texts or sentences where students must select the correct words. They are often used for the following purposes:

  1. To check knowledge of core course concepts (this could be a pre-check, formative exercise, or summative check).
  2. To check reading comprehension.
  3. To check vocabulary knowledge.
  4. To check word formation and/or grammatical competence.

If your goal is to test understanding of core concepts or reading comprehension

Write a summary of the concept or reading long enough to adequately test the target's knowledge, but short enough not to induce fatigue. Less than one typed page is probably adequate, but probably considerably less for young students or beginners.

Choose words in the text thatare key to understanding the concepts. Thesewill probably be verbs, nouns, and key adverbs.Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test vocabulary knowledge
If your goal is to test word formation/grammar:

Write a text using the target forms. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Remember that the goal is not vocabulary knowledge, so the core meanings of the stem words should be well known to the students.

Highlight the target words in the text. Provide alternatives with the same word stem, but different affixes. It is a good idea to get a colleague to test the test/exercise to make sure there are no surprises!
Enter any feedback you wish to provide the learner with-in the feedback field. This field can be left blank.
Well done!
Activity 2
Provide instruction on how the cloze activity should be completed. Default text will be entered if there are no changes to this field.
Complete the sentences with the correct verb. You have to do some adaptations to the verb in some cases.
University of Auckland
If this option is checked, submitted answers with different capitalization will be marked as incorrect.

1. An armed boy held up the village store last week. 

2. The prisoners always have the desire to break out of the daily rutine in jail. 

3. They were arrested after the police were tipped off. 

4. I was beat up badly by two guys who stole my wallet.

5. I got angry because Ana walked off with my jacket, I couldn't believe it. 

6. This morning I was running late for work and I went through a red light, but luckily the police let me off .
If this option is set, each word will be marked as the learner types it rather than all the words being marked the end of the exercise.

Enter the text for the cloze activity in to the cloze field by either pasting text from another source or by typing text directly into the field.

To select words to hide, double click on the word to select it and click on the Hide/Show Word button below.

More than one possible answer can be defined enclosing them with pipes (|). I.e.: |dog|cat|bird|

If left unchecked a small number of spelling and capitalization errors will be accepted. If checked only an exact match in spelling and capitalization will be accepted.

For example: If the correct answer is Elephant then both elephant and Eliphant will be judged "close enough" by the algorithm as it only has one letter wrong, even if "Check Capitalization" is on.

If capitalization checking is off in the above example, the lowercase e will not be considered a mistake and eliphant will also be accepted.

If both "Strict Marking" and "Check Capitalization" are set, the only correct answer is "Elephant". If only "Strict Marking" is checked and "Check Capitalization" is not, "elephant" will also be accepted.

1. An armed boy held up the village store last week. 

2. The prisoners always have the desire to break out of the daily rutine in jail. 

3. They were arrested after the police were tipped off. 

4. I was beat up badly by two guys who stole my wallet.

5. I got angry because Ana walked off with my jacket, I couldn't believe it. 

6. This morning I was running late for work and I went through a red light, but luckily the police let me off.

Cloze exercises are texts or sentences where students must fill in missing words. They are often used for the following purposes:

  1. To check knowledge of core course concepts (this could be a pre-check, formative exercise, or summative check).
  2. To check reading comprehension.
  3. To check vocabulary knowledge.
  4. To check word formation and/or grammatical competence.

If your goal is to test understanding of core concepts or reading comprehension

Write a summary of the concept or reading long enough to adequately test the target's knowledge, but short enough not to induce fatigue. Less than one typed page is probably adequate, but probably considerably less for young students or beginners.

Select words in the text thatare key to understanding the concepts. Thesewill probably be verbs, nouns, and key adverbs.Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test vocabulary knowledge

Write a text using the target vocabulary. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Highlight the target words in the text. Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test word formation/grammar:

Write a text using the target forms. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Remember that the goal is not vocabulary knowledge, so the core meanings of the stem words should be well known to the students.

Highlight the target words in the text. Provide alternatives with the same word stem, but different affixes. It is a good idea to get a colleague to test the test/exercise to make sure there are no surprises!
Enter any feedback you wish to provide the learner with-in the feedback field. This field can be left blank.
Let´s test your knowledge!
What crime did they commit?
Provide instruction on how the cloze activity should be completed. Default text will be entered if there are no changes to this field.

Now that you know about the different types of crimes and criminals  and some verbs related to this, it is your turn to put it into practice. 

Read the crime descriptions, with the information given decide what type of crime was commited.
University of Auckland
If this option is checked, submitted answers with different capitalization will be marked as incorrect.

1.  Manslaughter : David Smith got drunk one night  and decided to drive home. As he turned a corner he crashed into another car and killed the driver

2. Fraud : Alicia pretended to start a business and persuaded some people to lend her some money. She used the money to go on a holiday to the Carribean. 

3.  Murder : Raul  pulled out a gun from  his pocket and shot the bank guard five times in the head. 

4. Theft : Pedro stole a computer from the company he worked for.

5.   Hijacking : Vicente took a pistol and ordered the pilot to fly to Miami. 

6.  Arson : Carlos set fire to his school after failing all his exams. 

7. Kidnapping : Paul and Jennifer stopped the millionaire Bill Gates outside his home and forced him to go with them. They demanded 50 million dollars from the family to free him.

8. Burglary : My neighbor waited until night to carry out his crime. He forced the window carefully and climbed into the house. He was walking off with the TV when I tipped off the police. 

8. Rape : Sara told me her boyfriend forced her to have sex with him. I just want to beat him up but my friend is protecting him.

9. Smuggling   : Yesterday night a 12 year old girl was caught at the customs with 5 kilogramms of cocaine in her luggage. That really surprised me! 

10. Bribe : A police lost his job beacuse he accepted money from a beautiful woman, the woman was supposed to get a speeding ticket.
If this option is set, each word will be marked as the learner types it rather than all the words being marked the end of the exercise.

If left unchecked a small number of spelling and capitalization errors will be accepted. If checked only an exact match in spelling and capitalization will be accepted.

For example: If the correct answer is Elephant then both elephant and Eliphant will be judged "close enough" by the algorithm as it only has one letter wrong, even if "Check Capitalization" is on.

If capitalization checking is off in the above example, the lowercase e will not be considered a mistake and eliphant will also be accepted.

If both "Strict Marking" and "Check Capitalization" are set, the only correct answer is "Elephant". If only "Strict Marking" is checked and "Check Capitalization" is not, "elephant" will also be accepted.

2. Fraud : Alicia pretended to start a business and persuaded some people to lend her some money. She used the money to go on a holiday to the Carribean.

7. Kidnapping : Paul and Jennifer stopped the millionaire Bill Gates outside his home and forced him to go with them. They demanded 50 million dollars from the family to free him.

8. Burglary : My neighbor waited until night to carry out his crime. He forced the window carefully and climbed into the house. He was walking off with the TV when I tipped off the police. 

8. Rape : Sara told me her boyfriend forced her to have sex with him. I just want to beat him up but my friend is protecting him.

9. Smuggling   : Yesterday night a 12 year old girl was caught at the customs with 5 kilogramms of cocaine in her luggage. That really surprised me!

An activity can be defined as a task or set of tasks a learner must complete. Provide a clear statement of the task and consider any conditions that may help or hinder the learner in the performance of the task.
Describe the tasks the learners should complete.
Write in your notebook 5 sentences using the vocabulary you learned in this activity: types of crimes and criminals and phrasal verbs. Try to combine the vocabulary in a sentence.
Activity validation
Validate your activity

Duration:
10:00

To finish this activity you will answer a validation quiz. It is important to consider these things:

  1. To get this activity validated, you must score at least 80% in this quiz.
  2. In order not to lose points, it is important to check not only your answer but your spelling too.

Click here:                validation quiz

The majority of a learning resource will be establishing context, delivering instructions and providing general information. This provides the framework within which the learning activities are built and delivered.
Use this field to enter text. This iDevice has no emphasis applied although limited formatting can be applied to text through the text editing buttons associated with the field.
